editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: DEATH REPEAL'D BY A THANKFVLL MEMORIALL Sent from CHRIST-CHURCH in OXFORD, CELEBRATING THE NOBLE DESERTS OF the Right Honourable, PAVLE, Late Lord VIS-COUNT BAYNING of SUDBURY. Who changed his Earthly Honours Iune the 11. 1638.
OXFORD, Printed by Leonard Lichfield Printer to the Vniver≈øity, for Francis Bowman. M.D.C.XXXVIII.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT HONOVRABLE THE LADY PENELOPE DOWAGER of the late VIS-COVNT BAYNING.

lg.l: GREAT Lady, Humble partners of like griefe
In bringing Comfort may de≈øerve beliefe,
Becau≈øe they Feele, and Feyne not: Thus we ≈øay
Vnto Our ≈øelves, Lord Bayning, though away,
Js ≈øtill of Chri≈øt-Church; ≈øomewhat out of ≈øight,
As when he travel'd, or did bid good night,
And was not ≈øeen long after; now he ≈øtands
Remov'd in Worlds, as heretofore in Lands;
But is not Lo≈øt. The ≈øpight of Death can never
Divide the Christian, though the Man it ≈øever.
The like we ≈øay to You: He's ≈øtill at home,
Though out of reach; as in ≈øome upper roome,
Or ≈øtudy: for His Place is very high,
His Thought is Vi≈øion; now mo≈øt properly
Return'd he's Yours as ≈øure, as e're hath been
The Iewell in Your Cask, ≈øafe though un≈øeen.
You know that Friends have Eares as well as Eyes,
We Heare, Hee's well and Living, that Well dies.

div.head: ON THE DEATH OF THE RIGHT HONOVRABLE THE LORD VISCOVNT BAYNING.

lg.l: THough after Death, Thanks le≈ø≈øen into Prai≈øe,
And Worthies be not crown'd with gold, but bayes;
Shall we not thank? To prai≈øe Thee all agree;
We Debtors mu≈øt out doe it, heartily.
De≈øerv'd Nobility of True De≈øcent,
Though not ≈øo Old in Thee grew Ancient:
We number not the Tree of Branched Birth,
But Genealogie of Vertue, ≈øpreading forth
To many births in value. Piety,
True Valour, Bounty, Meekne≈ø≈øe, Mode≈øty,
The≈øe noble off-≈øprings ≈øwell Thy Name as much,
As Richards, Edwards, three, foure, twenty ≈øuch:
For in thy Per≈øon's linage ≈øurnam'd are
The great, the good, the wi≈øe, the ju≈øt, the faire.
One of the≈øe ≈øtiles innobles a whole ≈øtemme;
If all be found in One, what race like Him!
Long ≈øtayres of birth, unle≈ø≈øe they likewi≈øe grow
To higher vertue, mu≈øt de≈øcend more low.
WheÃÑ water comes through numerous veins of lead,
'Tis water ≈øtill; Thy blood from One pipes head
Grew Aqua-vitae ≈øtreight, with ≈øpirits fill'd,
As not traduc'd, but rais'd, ≈øublim'd, di≈øtill'd.
Nobility farre ≈øpread, I may behold,
Like the expanded skie, or di≈ø≈øolv'd gold,
Much rarified; I ≈øee't contracted here
Into a ≈øtarre, the ≈øtrength of all the ≈øpheare;
Extracted like th' Exlixir from the Mine,
And highten'd ≈øo, that 'tis too ≈øoone divine.
Divinity continues not beneath;
Alas nor He: But though He pa≈ø≈øe by death,
He that for many liv'd, gaines many lives
After hee's dead: Each friend, and ≈øervant ≈øtrives
To give him breath in prai≈øe; this Ho≈øpital,
That Pri≈øon, Colledge, Church, mu≈øt needs recall
To mind their Patron; who≈øe rich legacies
In forreigne lands, and under other skies
To them a≈ø≈øign'd, ≈øhew that his heart did even
In France love England, as in England Heaven.
Heav'n well perceiv'd this double pious love,
Both to his Country here, and that above:
Therefore the day, that ≈øaw Him landed here,
Hath ≈øeen him landed in his Haven there;
The ≈øelfe-≈øame day (but two yeares interpos'd)
Saw Sun and Him round ≈øhining twice and clos'd.
No Citizen ≈øo covetous could be
Of getting wealth, as of be≈øtowing, He;
His Body, and E≈øtate went as they came,
Stript of Appendix Both, and left the ≈øame
But in th' Originall; Nece≈ø≈øity
Deve≈øted one, the other Charity.
It co≈øt him more to cloth his ≈øoule in death,
Then e're to cloth his fle≈øh for ≈øhort-liv'd breath;
And whereas Lawes exact from Niggards dead
A Portion for the Poore, they now are ≈øaid
To moderate His bounty: never ≈øuch
Was knowne but once, that men ≈øhould give too much:
A Tabernacle then was built, and now
The like in heav'n is purchas'd: Learn you how;
Partly by building Men, and partly by
Erecting walls, by new-found Chymi≈øtry,
Turning of Gold to Stones. Our Chri≈øt-Church Pile,
Great Henrie's monument, ≈øhall grow a while
With Bayning's Trea≈øure; who away hath took,
Like tho≈øe at Westmin≈øter, to fill a nook
'Mong≈øt beds of Kings. Thus ≈øpeak, ≈øpeak while we may
For Stones will ≈øpeak when We are hu≈øh'd in Clay.

div.head: In obitum Illu≈øtri≈ø≈øimi Vicecomitis BAYNING

l.hi: QVid voveat dulci nutricula majus Alumno,

Quam bona Fortunae, Corporis, at
que Animi?
En haec Heroe hoc ≈øimul omnia; quid petat ultra?
Quid potius? Coelum: quod novus ho≈øpes habet.

div.head: The ≈øame Engli≈øhed.
div.l: Can Nur≈øe choo≈øe in her ≈øweet babe more to find,
Then goods of Fortune, Body, and of Mind?
Loe here at once all this: what greater bli≈ø≈øe
Can'≈øt hope or wi≈øh? Heaven; why there he is.

div.head: On the Death of the Right Honourable the Lord Vi≈øcount BAYNING.

lg.l: SO when an ha≈øty vigour doth di≈øclo≈øe
An early flame in the more forward Ro≈øe,
That Rarene≈ø≈øe doth de≈øtroy it: Wonders owe
This to them≈øelves ≈øtill, that they cannot grow.
Such Ripene≈ø≈øe was His Fate: Thus to appeare
At fir≈øt, was not hereafter to ≈øtay here.
Who thither fir≈øt ≈øteps, whither others tend,
When He ≈øets forth is at the Iourney's end.
But as Short things mo≈øt vigour have, and we
Find Force the Recompence of Brevity;
So was it here: Compactedne≈ø≈øe gave Strength,
The Life was Clo≈øe, though not ≈øpun out at Length.
Nothing lay idle in't: Experience Rules,
Men ≈øtrengthn'd Books, & Cities ≈øea≈øon'd Schools.
Nor did he i≈ø≈øue forth to come Home thence
(As ≈øome) le≈ø≈øe Man, then they goe out from hence:
Who think new Ayre new Vices may create,
And ≈øtamp Sinne Lawful in Another State;
Who make Exotick Cu≈øtomes Native Arts,
And Loo≈øe Italian Vices Engli≈øh Parts:
He naturaliz'd Perfections only; gain'd
A round and ≈øolid mind, ≈øeverely train'd,
And manag'd his de≈øires; brought oft checkt Sen≈øe
Vnto the ≈øway of, Rea≈øon comming thence
His owne acquaintance, morgag'd unto none,
But was him≈øelfe His owne po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion.
Thus ≈øtarres by journying ≈øtill, gaine, and di≈øpen≈øe,
Drawing at once, and ≈øhedding influence:
Thus Spheares by Regular Motion doe encrea≈øe
Their Tunes, and bring their Di≈øcords into Peace.
Hence knew He his owne value, ne're put forth
Honour for Merit; Pow'r in≈øtead of Worth:
Nor, when He poyz'd him≈øelfe, would He prevaile
By Wealth, and make his Mannors turne the ≈øcale.
De≈øert was only ballanc'd; nor could we
Say my Lord's Rents were only Weight, not He:
Only one ≈ølight he had; from being Small
Vnto him≈øelfe, He came Great unto all:
But Great by no mans Ruine: For who will
Say that his Seat e're made the next Seate ill?
No Neighb'ring-village was unpeopled here
'Cau≈øe it dur≈øt bound a Noble Eye too neere.
Who could e're ≈øay my Lord, and the next Mar≈øh
Made frequent Herriots? or that any har≈øh
Oppre≈ø≈øive u≈øage made Young Lives ≈øoone fall?
Or who could His ≈øeven thou≈ø and bad Ayre call?
He ble≈ø≈øings ≈øhed: Men knew not to whom more,
The Sun, or Him, they might impute their ≈øtore.
No rude exaction, or licentious times
Made his Revenewes Others, or His Crimes:
Nor are his Legacies poore-mens pre≈øent teares,
Or doe they for the future rai≈øe their feares.
No ≈øuch contrivance here as to profe≈ø≈øe
Bounty, and with Large Mi≈øeries feed the Le≈ø≈øe;
Fat ≈øome with their owne almes; be≈øtow, and pill;
And Common Hungers with Great Famines fill,
Making an Hundred Wretches endow Tenne,
Taking the Field, and giving a Sheafe then:
As Robbers, whom they ≈øpoile, perhaps will lend
Small ≈øummes to helpe them to their journey's end.
All was untainted here, and th' Author ≈øuch,
That every gift from Him grew twice as much.
We, who erewhile did boa≈øt his pre≈øence, doe
Now boa≈øt a ≈øecond grace, his bounty too;
Bounty, was judgment here: for he be≈øtowes
Not who di≈øper≈øeth, but who giues and knowes.
And what more wi≈øe de≈øigne, then to renew,
And dre≈ø≈øe the bre≈øt, from which he knowledge drew!
Thus pious men, ere their departure, fir≈øt
Would crown the fountain which had quencht their thir≈øt.
Hence ≈øtrive we all his memory to engro≈ø≈øe,
Our Common Love before, but now Our Lo≈ø≈øe.

div.head: Vpon the Death of the Right Honourable, the Lord Vi≈øcount BAYNING.

lg.l: O Had He been at Rome again, for there
The Mercy of his Sickne≈ø≈øe did him ≈øpare;
Acknowledging this Law, that 'tis but ju≈øt
The place which gave him breath, ≈øhould make him du≈øt:
That as we have a Native ≈øoile, ≈øo we
Ought not to beare Forreine Mortality.
Though He was only di≈øtant then from's grave
Some ≈øtore of Miles, not Years, and we can have
No wor≈øe then Ab≈øence, whether in the Tombe
He lye, or in a Climate live from home:
Yet had He been, though from our ≈øelves, remov'd
To any di≈øtance, if from death be≈øtow'd,
We would have buried Envy, bin content
His pre≈øence was to any people lent,
Bin glad ≈øome time was ≈øtill to come, though ≈ømall,
And could not long rejourne his funerall.
Death now came Ha≈øty on him, and ≈øo quick,
He ≈øearce had leave or time for to grow ≈øick,
But dy'd almo≈øt in Health, and you may plea≈øe
To call his very life his chiefe di≈øea≈øe.
The Vrne may triumph that the fatall dart
Hath wonne the ≈øpoile alone, without the Art
Or learned help of Phy≈øick, not a Graine
Or curious ≈øcruple from the Doctortane
Made up a skilfull wound, but he did dye
By the rude ≈øtroke of plain Mortality:

Which was not give ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶
‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ en his haire turn'd fro≈øt,
And wore the colour which his A≈øhes mu≈øt;
When all his Youth and Beauty were ≈øo ≈øpent,
That Age had made him his own Monument;
When it might be Humanity to kill,
And the mo≈øt deadly Drug might proue good-will:
But in a Spring of fre≈øh and active Blood,
When there was nothing old in Him, but Good;
He had Graie vertues, and by view of's mind
Not yeares, he was ≈øo ≈øoon to heaven de≈øign'd.
He who ≈øaw that, could ≈øee He liv'd his Age
Of foure≈øcore, made his Race a Pilgrimage.
And ≈øtill he lives, and from his late≈øt night
Breaks out unto the world a glorious light,
Getting this conque≈øt over death, that He
Was ≈ønatch'd away in's Liberality,
In's Piety to build, and care to frame
Such ≈øumptuous Trophies as will ≈øave his name.
Had he one vacant houre from Bounty ≈øpent,
And in that houre unto his grave been ≈øent;
'T had been le≈ø≈øe glory to his Fall, to dye
Iu≈øt in the ≈øleeping of his Charity:
But to be caught in Good, in Vertue ≈øtrook,
Made him Triumphant ere He earth for≈øook.
So did the ≈øtout Athenian ≈øtand in Death,
Rearing his Statue while he lo≈øt his Breath.

div.head: To the memory of the Honourable Lord BAYNING.

lg.l: FOrbeare yee whining Wits to rayle at Fate
In viler termes then Scolds at Billings-gate:
Nor brand poore Death with ba≈øer Epithites
Then Textor has when of the Divell he writes:
All ≈øuch ill-≈øounding Dirges yee can have
Are but as Mandrakes planted on his grave.
Your teares are now ridiculous; were I
A Poet, I would write Deaths Elogie.
Shee here was ju≈øt, and courteous; Suppole
We ≈øhould in Ianuary ≈øee a Ro≈øe
Full blown, would we not pull't, and think it worth
Myriads of tho≈øe that May or Iune brings forth?
This early fruitfull Flowre being ripe i'th' Spring
Was a fit Pre≈øent for our Soveraigns King.
Should ≈øhee have left it for the Summers Fly,
Or Autumn's Worme, 't had been ill hu≈øwifery:
Shee cropt it ≈øuddenly, and was as nice
In killing Him, as Prie≈øts a Sacrifice.
Le≈øt any brui≈øe ≈øhould happen, 'twas her ≈øtrife
To cut, and not ≈øaw off his thread of life.
Shee knew he was prepar'd, and therefore ≈øent
No Gout to tell him that he mu≈øt repent.
A tedious ≈øickne≈ø≈øe had his Friends more greiv'd;
He then had longer died, not longer liv'd.
We judge a Keeper dull and hard of heart,
That wounds the timorous Dear in every part.
He doth in Skill and Courte≈øy excell,
That kills not hurts, and makes his Prey die Well.
Deaths quicker blow did then no injury,
But that it hindred Doctors of a Fee.
There's none will cur≈øe a winde cau≈øe it doth ≈øend
Their ≈øhip too ≈øoon unto the journies end.
Doe any Trav'lers think their Hor≈øes ≈øinne,
Vnle≈ø≈øe they bring them Late unto their Inne?
He now a Voyage took; He that did goe
To France and Rome, mu≈øt needs ≈øee Heaven too.
What would you ≈øay of him that went about
To ≈øee all England, and left London out!
'Twas for His Glory that He died ≈øo ≈øoon;
Should He have lingred till his after-noon,
We had ≈øu≈øpected Him of gro≈ø≈øer blood;
By ≈øhort continuance we judge things Good:
A fine pure ≈øilken ve≈øture cannot weare
So long as garments weav'd of hemp or hayre.
By this his early fall He did pre≈øent
The Gods with a perfume of ≈øweeter ≈øent.
Tapers that burne and langui≈øh 'till they come
To th'≈øocket, leave ill odours in the roome.
Lords count it a di≈øparagement, if they
Should not have ≈øuits which ≈øeem new every day.
Had it not injur'd his high Soule to weare
His Body till the fle≈øh had look'd thred-bare?
Seeing he died ≈øo Young, it may be ≈øaid
That he's tran≈øplanted rather then decay'd:
By his fre≈øh looks, and his faire youthfull chin
We may believe he's made a Cherubin.
Tho≈øe then that wet his Hear≈øe, and vainly Cry,
Not Mourne, but Pine at His Eternity.
Envy that here ≈øtill follow'd Him, is made
After His death, the ≈øhadow of His ≈øhade.
Whil'≈øt others ≈øtudied how to loo≈øe their time,
Thinking that Logick would their Birth be≈ølime,
As if it were Gentile not to Di≈øpute;
It was his chief ambition to confute;
Who not alone aym'd to de≈øerve his Grace,
But ≈øeem'd by paines to wi≈øh a Students place.
Though Heralds did to Him great Names afford,
He heard Sir BAYNING ≈øooner then My Lord.
Le≈øt the proud noi≈øe of Titles might beginne
Thoughts that might ≈øwell His Plenty into ≈øinne,
Arts and Religion gnarded them; He knew
His Fortunes were but Crimes, without the≈øe two;
And in a noble ≈øcorne di≈ødain'd to ≈øpell
The Lord ith' Scutchion more then Chronicle.
His Pride was to be Eloquent, and Able
As is Our Dor≈øet at the Councell-Table.
He knew unle≈ø≈øe a bright Retinue come
Of Vertues too, Man's but a glorious Tombe,
Carv'd ore with names of Honour, which may win
The eyes applau≈øe, but is but Stench within.
Did you but read his Will you'd think that He
Had been a Reverend Bi≈øhop; Lords there be
That falling in their youth bequeath alone
Their Bodyes to our Churches, not a Stone,
Vnle≈ø≈øe for their Gwn Tombe; twas His high care
They ≈øhould his Lands as well as Carca≈ø≈øe ≈øhare.
As if he meant each place his Heire ≈øhould be,
He ble≈øt the Pri≈øons with his Charity.
Iayles are now Ho≈øpitalls; to ≈øome 'twill be
Not to be bayld or freed, a courte≈øy.
His Guifts will ≈øtill the New-gate Cries; we ≈øhall
Heare the cag'd Birds hereafter ≈øing, not ball.
Much doe we owe to him be≈øides that Plate,
Which is when full of fragments full of State:
The Knife and Voider's ≈øuch that to a Gue≈øt
Taking away is as a ≈øecond fea≈øt.
But the Example of his Life will be
To after times the riche≈øt Legacy.

div.head: To the Lady BAYNING.

lg.l: PArdon our Bold Teares, Madam, that we doe
Pre≈øume to joyn our ≈øelves Mourners with You.
Grief is no Herald; there's no Rule in Moanes,
We never ≈øtand on Titles in our Groanes.
Manners and Complement we prize the le≈ø≈øe,
Where a Confus'd ≈øad Griefe is the be≈øt dre≈ø≈øe:
Yet we doe hope You will no Cen≈øure make,
And Teares ≈øwoln up with Grief for Pride mi≈øtake;
Nor call our ≈øighs to th'Court of Honor, wee
Doe not lament for the Brave Company.
Where our own lo≈ø≈øe prompts us, you need not fear
Rivals in plaints, as Iealous of each Teare.
We all enjoy'd ≈øo much of Him, we dare
Allow You but a Part, and Common ≈øhare:
His Goodnes was ≈øo much diffus'd, we doe
Think we might love him without wrong to You.
May we not think him now but cro≈øs'd the Seas,
And count His Death 'mong other Voyages?
Sure, as no Land he here did travell o're
But what in's Study He had pa≈ø≈ø'd before,
And fir≈øt knew France and Spaine in England, ere
He was a Witne≈ø≈øe of their Actions there;
So was his pure Refined ≈øoule we know
So well acquainted with the place it now
More fully dwells in, 't may be truly ≈øaid
He had been much in Heavn'n ere he was Dead.
But this doth only cheat our Grief, the maine
Comfort's our Hope to ≈øee him here againe,
In that brave off-≈øpring which your Blood yet keeps
Alive in memory of Him that ≈øleeps.
Which when you ≈øhall give Birth to, He being gone
We all will count his Re≈øurrection.

div.head: On the Death of the Lord Vi≈øcount BAYNING.
div.l: VVHen Titles fall, and Death ambitious how
To rai≈øe his Triumph, makes ≈øome great one bow,
Not Cadmus teeth could halfe ≈øo ≈øoon infu≈øe
A ≈øoule, as can Their du≈øt in≈øpire a Mu≈øe;
Whiles death enlivens death, and mo≈øt wits have
Their Re≈øurrection from anothers Grave:
Nor were the wonder ≈øtrange thus to behold
Our Ice inflam'd, our Heat ≈øpring out of Cold,
Did all like BAYNING dye; did every Lord
More griefe for Vertue lo≈øt, then State afford,
How might bad ver≈øes be excus'd, when we
Found all writ truth, no other Poetry;
When height of Fancy left Expre≈ø≈øion weak,
Not able to Begin, much le≈ø≈øe to Speak
And tell to th'full, that hence whats e're cald ver≈øe,
Will be but Tribute due to this Mans hear≈øe?
Such was thy worth; who≈øe dawning prov'd that Light
Which aged beams ≈øend forth, to Thine true night:
Who≈øe Pa≈øtime ≈øpent in Oxford (for what more
Is it for Noble-men to turne Books ore?)
Prov'd Serious Play: True Honour does know how
To Ri≈øe to Vertue, not make Vertue Bow.
This Gaind Him Reverence, Young: Receiving, He
Gave to th'Univer≈øity a degree:
Thus Blo≈ø≈øom'd in his Bud, thus early wi≈øe
Grown now the Ioy, not Envy of mens eyes:
Travell's His Choice, not Refuge; unlike tho≈øe
Who what they want at Home, Abroad di≈øclo≈øe,
Pa≈ø≈øing this Country to ≈øhun that; thus round
Spend all their Own to out-run Forrein ground.
Lu≈øtre went with Him, and whiles He did pa≈ø≈øe,
That place was thought worth ≈øeeing where He was.
Rome entertain'd Him, which you then might call
The worlds Head ju≈øtly, when the Cardinall
Enrich'd by's Pre≈øents, found his Honour more
By what He added to his Princely ≈øtore.
Thus big with forreine Prai≈øes, Hee's come home,
But all was only here to find a Tombe:
Where we mu≈øt let him re≈øt, thus good, thus young;
For too much grief would doe His Vertues wrong;
Who≈øe Morn though clowded, ≈øee's His ha≈øtned years
Extended to their full in his Friends Tears.

div.head: On the Death of the Lord BAYNING.

lg.l: 'TIs not ambition drawes my juycele≈ø≈øe pen
Thus to di≈øtill a Po√´m; 'mong≈øt ≈øuch Men,
Or rather Gods of Poetry 'tis Pride
To come behind, Duty to be de≈øcri'd
I'th' li≈øt of Them; be≈øides I think't not fit
To rai≈øe a fire where floods of teares ≈øhould meet;
And Po√´try's a fire: but my Mu≈øe feares
A kindling from this urne, le≈øt drown'd with teares
It quickly turne to a≈øhes, and there be
Not a ≈øpark left to weepe an elegie.
Yet this, Great BAYNING'S dead! That's all I have
Or can ≈øpeak: Silence be≈øt becomes the Grave.
Yet this againe, Whil≈øt with us here He ≈øtriv'd
To outdoe Goodne≈ø≈øe, Bounty, All, He liv'd
His Character; who in his carriage than
Shew'd of him≈øelfe that, which no Po√´t can:
Who with his rare≈øt art, and choyce≈øt quill
Mu≈øt ≈øerve here only to expre≈ø≈øe him ill.
He was ≈øo pure, ≈øo ≈øpotle≈ø≈øe, ≈øo refind,
I took Him for ≈øome Angell, Soule, or Mind,
And think it no hyperbole to call
As others From, To heav'n this Angel's Fall.
I dare not write an Epitaph, for feare
The Vrne devoure my Ver≈øe, being ≈øo neare.
Yet thus much to their Honours at the Court,
(Two lo≈ø≈øes being knowne) I dare report,
(And 'tis no trea≈øon, the≈øe great names being read,
Herbert, and Bayning,) That all Vertues dead.

div.head: Vpon the Death of the Lord BAYNING.
div.l: MO≈øt ≈øacred hear≈øe, let it no ≈øin appeare,
If I upon thy Vrne doe weepe one teare!
I mu≈øt vent out my ≈øighes, it cannot be
A lo≈ø≈øe to us, to th'Vniver≈øitie,
Nay the whole Nation too, ≈øhould ≈ølightly pa≈ø≈øe
With this memoriall only, that He was:
Whil≈øt vertue ≈øhall be talk't of, till we ≈øhall
See nought that's good, thy memory cannot fall.
If e're we ≈øhall of ≈øome Vtopian heare
That never knew ra≈øh boldne≈ø≈øe, or cold feare,
No riot, no inju≈øtice, no exce≈ø≈øe,
Nor want, but all things in ju≈øt perfectne≈ø≈øe,
Actions ≈øo rul'd by prudence, and ≈øo all
As if his Vertues too were Naturall:
Then we ≈øhall think on BAYNING, ≈øweare that Hee,
That wrote it, meant it for His Hi≈øtory,
Proper to Him: Who≈øe Life was ≈øuch, we can
Scarce Iudge by which He greater Glory wan,
His Actions, or His Studies: what the Sage
Appropriate to the Wrinckle, and Old Age,
Knowledge, He compa≈øt in His Smoother Dayes,
And did Greene Pa≈ø≈øions up to Wi≈ødome rai≈øe.
Learning He thought no Burden, or to know
In Theoricke Vertues which He meant to ≈øhow;
Nor took't a Blemi≈øh to Nobility,
To have a Schollar's merited Degree,
E≈øteem'd it not ≈øufficient to heare
Compleate at home, and move but in one Spheare:
This Nation's too Contract; He does goe o're
Laden with Vertues to a Forreigne Shoare,
Not to exchange for Vice, or leave behind
To them the qualities of His Vertuous Mind;
As if He could no Traveller appeare,
If He return'd the ≈øame man He was here:
But He addes to it all the good France can
Call Proper Hers, all the Italian,
Which without Stay ≈øo ea≈øily He cou'd,
As if He were by In≈øpiration good.
To them He ≈øeem'd a Native, they would ≈øweate
He never was in any part but there:
He was ≈øo perfect without travell, we
In Him both Kingdomes Vertue here did ≈øee.
Thus fully furni≈øh't with all nature's dowre,
With Art, Experience, and Uertue's Power.
We ≈øaw him flouri≈øhing, but nature here
Begins her bounty quite exhau≈øt to feare;
And being of her lavi≈øh ≈øtore now dry,
She cuts Him downe full in Felicity.
Thus the be≈øt Fruits ju≈øt ripe are crop't, although
Without corruption they might longer grow.
But let this ≈øerve to ≈øtop our flowing teares,
That he dy'd Full: Age is not Numerous yeares;
Nor are they only Old that longe≈øt live,
Perfection and Uertue Fulne≈ø≈øe give.

div.head: Vpon the Death of the Lord Vi≈øcount BAYNING.

lg.l: TO weep one Great and Good, t'adorn his Hear≈øe
Who≈øe Life was above Chronicle, or Ver≈øe,

The≈øe Lines (alas!) they are not meant to give
Life to that Name, by which them≈øelves mu≈øt live:
That Name, Which doth employ each tongue, each Quill
To ≈øing His Prai≈øes, write his Chronicle.
BAYNING! Who≈øe very ≈øound perfumes the Ayre,
Commands a Reverence, and a li≈øtning eare.
Books were a Guide t' his Youth, and Company;
He thought of them with greater Charity

When He perus'd great Acts of Hi≈øtory,
His large thoughts did ≈øugge≈øt them Prophecy,
And Types of Him: when He the Uertues read,
And ≈øaw him≈øelfe tran≈øcrib'd, and copied,
He with a mode≈øty admir'd to find
Men ≈øo familiar with His Thoughts and Mind.
Sea≈øon'd, and balla≈øted with the≈øe, He then,

Not like to tho≈øe who travell to bring home
A Fa≈øhion, or to ≈øay they have ≈øeene Rome;
But to ob≈øerve each State and Policy,

And now returned home, when he begun
To practi≈øe here each Ob≈øervation,
While we behold Europes Epitome

Their Age by Vertues, not by Yeares we ≈øumme,

div.head: Vpon the Death of the honourable Lord Vi≈øcount BAYNING.
div.l: GReat Lord of Gho≈øts, we ≈øigh not out Thy Fall,
As only Thine, But th' Mu≈øes Funerall:
We weepe our Colledge ≈øecond Ruines; and
May Que≈øtion chiefly Death's erroneous Hand,
That yet we boa≈øt Intents alone, an Heape,
And Breaches, only not entitled cheape,
That Tho≈øe who entring Srangers, here would look,
Doe Pa≈ø≈øe ours, as a Colledge but mi≈øtooke:
Yet Orphan-like w'are not bereft of All,
The ≈øame that waile, ≈øhare too Thy ha≈øtned Fall;
Thy Piles bequeath'd yet, which ≈øhall firme and ≈øafe
With Wol≈øeys ≈øtand thy larger Epitaph.
But we not mi≈ø≈øe His Gifts alone, nor weepe
Mercy and Bounty only fallen a≈øleepe;
We boa≈øt no Scutchions, nor admire Thy Blood,
(Great Soule) but be≈øt de≈øcent by Learning Good,
Though Noble, mourning not the Lo≈ø≈øe of Thee,
As of a man but Vniver≈øitie:
Who grac'd our Schooles with a Degree; All Parts
Arriv'd, A Breathing Sy≈øtem of the Arts.
Not like our Silken Heires, who only bound
Their knowledge in the Sphear of Hauke or Hound,
And, there confin'd, limit their ≈øcant di≈øour≈øe,
Know more the Vaulting then the Mu≈øes Hor≈øe:
Who if They re≈øcue Time from Cards or Dice
To Lance or Sharpes, or ≈øome ≈øuch manly Prize,

But more ≈øeverely loo≈øe the Precious Day.
He could unriddle each Schoole-knot, untie
All, but Death's ≈øad contrived Fallacie:
For th' Stroke was Project Here, no Siege, no Art
Of lingring Death, or Preface to His Dart;
No tedious knotty Gout, or feveri≈øh Drought
But all as Soft and Peacefull as His Youth:
He only ≈ølept in Ha≈øt, as if to Die

So gliding we de≈øcry a ≈øtarry Ball,

Yet Thy ≈øhort Thread wee'le not revile, nor vexe
'Cau≈øe Th' art not imag'd in the Nobler Sexe;
For ≈øuch Tran≈øcriptions wee'le not anxious be,
Where we di≈øcover full Maturitie:
Ripened for Death Thou art Deceas'd, not Kill'd,
Nor is Thy great Name Peri≈øh'd, but Fulfill'd.
For what can adde unto the ju≈øte≈øt Height,
Who Hopes encrea≈øe to Glorie's perfect Weight,
To Him that had ≈øurvei'd all Forreigne parts,
Extracting not Their Vices, but Their Arts?
Th' Italian Brain, not Heate, was skil'd from Rheine

Their Deepe≈øt My≈øteries did only reach,

All Worth His Eye He view'd, that ≈øuch a Fall
Might ≈øhare a ≈øorrow Epidemicall,

div.head: Vpon the Death of the Lord Vi≈øcount BAYNING.

lg.l: DEath's Chambers are enrich't, and we may ≈øay
He did not Kill, but Stole This Prize away.

Yet that was but His Dro≈ø≈øe; ≈øearch, you will find

And le≈øt the Sophi≈øters might erre in this,
Granted Platonicke Metemp≈øeucho≈øis;
And did conclude, Maugre their Brains and Books,
Arts doe not alwaies lie in ill-fac'd looks;
And th'totred Gowne no longer now ≈øhould be
Held for an Embleme of Philo≈øophy.
He did adorne the Scarlet which he wore;
And made them Robes which were but Cloth before:
Titles were truths in him; Young, Fair, Rich, Learn'd
No complements, but Purcha≈øe, truly earn'd:
No Would-be-Wits maintain'd Hee at His Board,
Nought was in him ≈øu≈øpitious but The Lord:
Yet no Braines cloth'd, or Phancy fed Him; Hee
Rich in E≈øtate, as Ingenuitie:
And might have (without doubt of mi≈ø≈øing it,)
Petition'd for th' Monopoly of Wit:
To this va≈øt ma≈ø≈øe of Wealth He had a≈ø≈øign'd
As ample thoughts; no narrow, griping Mind,
Man≈øions by Indu≈øtry compos'd, not Hands
He fed on; and devour'd His Books, not Lands.
To who≈øe large Guifts we of this place mu≈øt owe;
Since that He thought His Owne He did be≈øtow.
Thy Volumes nam'd Our Library, and We
As well for Stones as Bookes indebted be.
For though no Founder of the place, yet mu≈øt
We ≈øay, thou rays'd≈øt our Buildings out o'th' Du≈øt;
Thou did≈øt bequeath 'em Their Nativitie;
And they doe Glory Their New-Birth from Thee.
Thus liv'≈øt Thou, Maugre Fate; Thy better Parts
Survive thus in our Memories, and Hearts:
Nor need'≈øt Thou claime ≈øtatued Antiquity;
Vertue Perpetuates Thy Nobility.
Since we may Date, from thy Departure hence,
The Dearth of Merit and Benevolence.

lg.l: SO ≈øets the Sunne, when ≈øtrait there doth en≈øue

dubiuÃÑ an cunis InfantiaÃÑ debuerit, an Lyceo.

lg.l: He that attempts to mourne thy noble Her≈øe,
Mu≈øt teach his griefe the Piety of Ver≈øe,
And all his teares in cha≈øt expre≈ø≈øions paint,
That every line may Canonize a Saint:
He ought to Preach in Numbers, as if Fate
Had de≈øtin'd Him for Bi≈øhop Laureate.
Who then ≈øhall weepe thy lo≈ø≈øe, who≈øe Acts we ≈øee fel,
Farre purer then our ve≈øtall phan≈øies be?
W'admire tho≈øe deeds which from Thee ≈ølightly
Thy Recreation fills the Chronicle:
And Poets ≈øhould be ≈øet to curbe the times,
Could their Wits be ≈øo Pious as Thy Crimes.
Thou did≈øt ingro≈ø≈øe all goodne≈ø≈øe ≈øo, that Wee
Scarce thought one Heroe dead, while we ≈øaw Thee.
We mi≈øs'd not Cato, Tully was not dumbe,
Thou could'≈øt (like him) but ≈øpeake, and overcome.
What Stratagem has Fate? thy fading breath
Summons ≈øage Brutus to a Second Death.
Soules trea≈øur'd up in Thee ru≈øh forth, and now
Some fall, that fell two thou≈øand yeares agoe.
Here prune your manners, you that only are
The walking Arras of the Court, who ≈øhare (face)
Your ≈øelves (like Hangins deckt with ≈øome ≈øtrange
T'attend the King only to trim the place.
Who≈øe weake Gentility does fall, and ri≈øe
As Periwigs and Sattins take their price:
Who≈øe carriage one may track, & find which Oath
Your Wor≈øhips ≈øwore in ≈øilk, and which in cloath.
If you could learne this ripene≈ø≈øe, it would teach
To court a Mi≈øtre≈ø≈øe in an unbought ≈øpeech;
And your owne Language might have power to move
A frozen coyne≈ø≈øe to a free Court-Love:
And make her y ‚Ä¢ e ≈øuch charming plea≈øures heare,
That her Soule know no re≈øidence but eare.
But I doe bla≈øt thy Her≈øe, and the≈øe weake Layes
Doe only u≈øher Some to ≈øing Thy Prai≈øe,
As ≈øcattered beames their dawning lu≈øtre broach,
Only to tell the world the Sun's approach.
As if the Prie≈øt ≈øhould butcher a cheape Lambe,
To fit the Altar for an Hecatombe.
He that will ≈øpeake Thee fully, mu≈øt have parts
Like to Thine Owne, and hunt Thee through all Arts:
His able yeares mu≈øt bud up, till he find,
What my≈øteries enrich't thy well-fraught mind;
Who did≈øt ≈øo wade through Natural things, that we
May ≈øhake off Nature now, and ≈øtudy Thee.
Had'≈øt thou bred low-pitch ‚Ä¢ t ve ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ ues, had thy Vein
Stoop'd to the ≈øhallow ebbe of vulgar ≈øtrain,
Each bu≈øie Mu≈øe had ≈øtrove to find a roome,
Where crowds of Epitaphs might load thy Tomb,
But now we feare to write, we dare no ‚Ä¢ ≈øtay
To bring ou ‚Ä¢ twilight Glances to thy Day:
Such is Thy Vertues flight, thou ≈øoar'≈øt ≈øo high,
Thy weake≈øt Acts aske our Hyperboly;
And all th' elaborate Accents we can lend,
Can ≈øcarce de≈øerve Thee where thou do≈øt offend.
Hence forth we'le prize our Mu≈øe at lower rate,
And what we can't expre≈ø≈øe, we'le imitate,
We'le Print Thee in our manners ≈øo, that then
Who finds Thee not in Records, may in Men.
They only, here, find their expre≈ø≈øions ≈øafe,
Who Act their Ver≈øe, and Live an Epitaph.

div.head: Vpon the Death of the Right Honourable Lord Vicecount BAYNING.
div.l: FOrgive me, His deare Monument, that I
V≈øurpe the Title of an Elegy;
And like a wandring Pa≈ø≈øenger doe crave
My unknowne teares may glaze his Epitaph!
Whoever heard his Travells, but did cea≈øe
To think Rome fal≈øe, or France with a di≈øea≈øe?
So farre from an outlandi≈øh Taint, that Hee
Return'd a cha≈øter Mind from Italie.
Learne here you wilde Apo≈øtates that deface
Your Native Soules, and mold 'em to the Place;
So that each Country gives you a new Birth,
Antaeus like reviving from the Earth:
BAYNING did ≈øcorne to change him≈øelfe but then
When farthe≈øt off, He was an Engli≈øh-man:
Our Lawes ≈øtill kept Him Company: for they
Were the Geography, and rule of 's way:
So that to forreigne parts He did appeare
Rather Emba≈ø≈øadour, then Sojourner.
Why did He ≈øcape His Travells thus, O why
Did he fall downe with ≈øuch Tranquillity?
Horrour becomes a Young man's Death, to lie
Bedew'd with Blood is a brave ob≈øequie.
Surfets, Con≈øumptions are but Female Knives,
Nor doe they ≈ønatch, but ≈øteale away our Lives.
Fates did not know thy Spirit, when they ≈øent
So weake a dart to bla≈øt thy Monument:
Thy Genius was too mighty to endure
That extreame cowardize, to die Secure.
But ≈øince it did our great Commander plea≈øe,
Thus to inflict the Death of a di≈øea≈øe;
In earne≈øt of our Loves, O let it be
Our wi≈øh to fall Secure, becau≈øe like Thee.
For Thy ≈øake then may Feavers be our Meate,
And 't prove a Surfet henceforth but to Eate:
None can de≈øire to live, unle≈ø≈øe he be
Seduc'd perhaps t'enjoy Thy Legacie.
'Tis Thy owne freene≈ø≈øe bribes us now to live,
Since 't were ingratitude not to ≈øurvive.
Our Buildings by Thy Piety ≈øhall ≈øtand
No Ruines now, but Trophyes of Thy Hand:
The Roomes ≈øhall be Thy Piles, we will preferre
Their beauteous Order to thy Character:
When Printed on the doores with loaded eyes
The Pa≈ø≈øenger may read HERE BAYNING LIES.

div.head: On the Death of the Lord Vi≈øcount BAYNING.
div.l: SInce Sadnes crowns Your hear≈øe, & Mourners
Be≈øtow with ≈øighs, & tears, a Method too
Of grieving for your death, that we may ≈øee doe
A good Contrivance though in Mi≈øery:
Since among all that mourn, none Order lack,
The Wits in Rime, Your other Friends in Black.
Pardon my grief, that dares a≈ø≈øume that Dre≈ø≈øe,
For ≈øcatter'd in wild Fancles 'twould ≈øeem le≈ø≈øe:
Yet doe I not pre≈øume my ver≈øe may give
Ought, that may cau≈øe Your memory to live:
I leave that great imployment to the Pen
Of Abler fancies, more Di≈øcerning Men;
That can Di≈øtingui≈øh vertues, and be≈øt know
Which froÃÑ Complexion, which froÃÑ Breeding flow,
Which are Innate, and which Infus'd, that can
But with one glaunce decipher a whole man.
'Tis fancy 'enough in me, if I can weepe
Your Body, not as Dead, but fall'n a ≈øleepe.
Since no Continu'd greif, or lingring pain
No Trick o'th' State, nor ≈øad ≈øtroak hath it ≈ølain:
It goes fre≈øh to the grave, before the ≈øinnes
Have ≈øea≈øon'd it, that Age, and Bu≈øine≈ø≈øe brings:
Where let it ≈øleep ≈øecure, hence coming fit
T'embalme and keep the Odours, not they It.
The groans, and ≈øighes, that parting now it weares,
The Marble ≈øhall ≈øupply with frequent Teares.

div.head: On the death of the Honourable Lord Vi≈ø-count BAYNING.

lg.l: HEnce froÃÑ This Tomb, you that have only cho≈øe
To Mourn for Ribbands, & the ≈øadder Cloths,
That Buy your Grief froÃÑ th' Shop; & de≈øperat lye
For a new Cloak till the next Lord ≈øhall Dye;
You that ≈øhed only wine, and think when all
The Banquet's pa≈øt, there's no more Funerall:
You that ≈øell Teares, and only Weepe for Gaine,
I dare not ≈øay you Mourn, but fill the Traine:
Nor mu≈øt we Grieve His Titles lo≈ø≈øe, and tell
The vainer World, that 'twas a Great Man Fell:
Tis not enough that we His Birth rehear≈øe;
And only Write His Armes in≈øteed of Ver≈øe,
Or Steale Notes from His Scutcheon; perhaps we
Might Mourn Him thus in perfect Heraldry:
But 'tis a Strain too low, nor wil't ≈øuffice
For Epitaph, that Here His Lord≈øhip Lyes:
Thus I could be content to Weep His Fame,
Where nothing el≈øe was great, be≈øides the Name;
Whence Learning felt an Exile; where That Word
Of Vertue ≈øounded Lower then my Lord:
He whom we ≈øadly Mourne (hear this all You
Wrapt up in Chaines) was Rich in Learning too.
A Colledge was His Home; He did not here
Sit ≈øtill a while, and only change His Ayre,
As ≈øome, who Iourney hither, and are grown
But to this Art of wearing a ≈øilk Gowne;
Who, 'mong≈øt Their other lo≈ø≈øe of Time, doe ≈øtill
Count the halfe-year thus ≈øpent again≈øt Their Will;
Who fain would cro≈ø≈øe the Seas, & think, that They
Have Travell'd thus far only out o'th' way:
Nor did he count a Lord in a Degree
A Learned Mon≈øter of Nobility,
As if ≈øome Envious Fate ≈øtrove to Maintaine
That only Ignorance ≈øhould wear a Chaine.
Gold was not all His Trea≈øury; We may
Reckon His Wealth in more then ≈øhining Clay;
Summe up His Stock of Arts and Knowledge; you
That prize th'E≈øtate count in His Study too;
This is the Style of Honour, which we boa≈øt
In Him, who≈øe Fame doth ≈øtill Survive His Gho≈øt.
Nor quarrell We with Fate, for we ≈øhould wrong
His Vertues now, to grieve that He Dy'd Young:
One of His worth is alwaies full of Yeares;
He Dy'd too ≈øoon by nothing but our Teares,
Ripe Early, and prepar'd for Heaven, He
Had all of Age, but the Infirmity:
He was Religious and Stay'd, as One
Whom Four-≈øcore years thru≈øt to Devotion:
One of That flowing Charity, as if ≈øtill
In ev'ry Guift He did intend a Will:
How He Bequeath'd His Almes! to all ≈øo free,
What ever He Be≈øtowd, was Legacy.
Thus He had Many Heyres; and the ble≈øt Poore
Did only Multiply His Succe≈ø≈øour.
But I'le not ≈øumme His Vertues; H'embrac't more
Then all Philo≈øophy did Talk before;
They only did Di≈øpute His Life, and might,
Had They known Him, been better Skild to Write.

div.head: Vpon the Death of the Lord Vi≈øcount BAYNING.
div.l: VVErt Thou an ancient Cor≈øe, of a gray head,
So ≈øpent, as to be thought run out, not dead;
Had'≈øt Thou endur'd long gowtes, or longer rage
Of Aches, and at la≈øt dyed of long age;
At ≈øuch a funerall our Teares were lo≈øt,
Where the grave makes not, but receives a Gho≈øt.
Thou, when not ripe enough to live, did≈øt fall,
Even when thy Lady might Thee Lady call;
And like an early ≈øpring did≈øt ≈øhow to th' eye,
Signes of a fruitfull Autumne, and then dye.
Yet though Thou dy'd≈øt a Blo≈ø≈øome, we were tho≈øe
Who could fore≈øee Thee blown, and judge Thee Ro≈øe.
Thy after life was wrapt up in this bud,
As in a ≈øprout a faire flower's under≈øtood.
And as when men file rocks for Iewels, th'Ore
Shows ≈øparks, which would be ≈øtones two Ages more:
So we might ≈øay, had this young Diamond grown,
That which now twinkled, then had lightning thrown:
And as rich Exudations ≈øweat from th' Tree,
Are fir≈øt ≈øoft gumms, not toucht, would Amber be:
Or as in th'Indyes men finde wealthy Mould,
Which the next generation diggs up gold.
So Thou lack'≈øt but Concoction, ≈øeaven years more
Had made tho≈øe vertues true Mine, which died Ore.
Nay thou wert Bullion now, and we had ≈øeen,
Had≈øt Thou liv'd longer, Ma≈ø≈øe had Medalls been.
Thy forwardne≈ø≈øe lackt only ≈øtampe, and rate;
Thou wert true ≈øilver, but uncoyn'd by th'State.
Which did perceive thy title was as good
To honours, by thy Hopefulne≈ø≈øe, as blood.
And had'≈øt Thou ≈øtaid but to be call'd to th'Board,
The Worthy Man had taken place oth' Lord.
Then had we ≈øeen from Letters 'mong≈øt us ≈øowne
Thy Prince had Emba≈ø≈øyes and Coun≈øells mowne.
When that, which Thou Philo≈øophy took'≈øt in,
Had come forth great Example, and Life bin.
Thy vertues were not le≈ø≈øe, becau≈øe yet greene,
They might more ≈øea≈øon'd, but not more have been:
Broader they might have bin, & ≈øhown more ≈øweld,
Yet had the Leafe not more then th'Ingot held.
As from a clue Workmen large hangings call,
Yet all the ≈øilke in th' Arras, was ith' Ball.
In ≈øhort lives, great parts ha≈øten, and come quick,
And where they want roome to be va≈øt, are thick.
Even thy raw promi≈øes were perfect, lackt
Time but to make them aged, not exact.
Vntraveld Thou wert Learned, yet the Book
In Thee fre≈øh learning from thy Travells took.
Thou cam'≈øt home ≈øober froÃÑ light Nations, France
Taught Thee to ≈øit in Councell, not to dance.
Italian Policy Thou brought'≈øt away,
Yet wert not made more able to betray:
Their Plots had been made Service, and that skill
Had been taught to Pre≈øerve, which us'd to Kill.
Thy Merit, not thy Bowle, had made Thee Great;
No Office had fal'n to Thee by thy Meat.
Thou did≈øt returne ≈øo innocent, we could call
Nothing Italian but thy Funerall:
That was ≈øo ≈øudden, no ≈øucce≈ø≈øours pill
Did Pope with more ha≈øt, then thy ≈øurfet kill.
Prophets tran≈ølated were ≈øo ravi≈øh't, bate
The ≈øen≈øe oth'pang, thy death was change, not fate.
Had'≈øt Thou bequeath'd us nought, thy name had ≈øtill
Bin Legacy, t'have bin oth' hou≈øe was Will:
And we in thy deare lo≈ø≈øe think w'are bereft
Of more, then if Thou had'≈øt us whole heyres left.
Now ≈øince, like Wol≈øey, th'art expir'd, and gone,
We only can pay Reverence to thy Stone;
Which equall to His will this glory winne,
Thou help'≈øt to Fini≈øh what He did Beginne.

div.head: To the Right Vertuous, and my much Honoured the Lady PENELOPE BAYNING.
div.l: TO All, that hath been ≈øaid, I Eccho am,
Though with an hoar≈øer Voice return the ≈øame:
But His was Clean, and Faire as his Intent,
And His Performances His Complement;
Who had more Vertue then deriv'd froÃÑ th'wombe,
And more Perfections then are writ on's Tombe;
Honour, ≈øuch as the King could not be≈øtow,
Vnle≈ø≈øe his Great Example made him ≈øo;
Who brought froÃÑ Rome, as did his Prince froÃÑ Spain,
Religion, and His very ≈øelfe againe;
Here lies That Lord All This: who had been more,
Had time but lent concoction to his Ore.
Be witne≈ø≈øe √¥ my Griefe then (for I may
Now challenge ≈øomething in Him being Clay)
What Thoughts, what Spirits, what InteÃÑts, what Seeds
What Acts, what CouÃÑ≈øels, what De≈øignes, what Deeds
Are bla≈øted in His fall! But lea≈øt I may
Encrea≈øe your Night by telling what great Day
Would hence have ri≈øen, let me only beare
